CALIFORNIA

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM (CalARP)



RISK MANAGEMENT PROGRAM (RMP)



PROCESS SAFETY MANAGEMENT PROGRAM (PSM)



Anhydrous Ammonia Refrigeration, Wastewater pH Adjustment;

Sulfur Dioxide Systems



E & J Gallo Winery Facility



Revised June 2014





EXECUTIVE SUMMARY







E & J Gallo Modesto Winery (hereafter referred to as Gallo Winery) has prepared a CalARP, Chemical Risk Management Program and Process Safety Management Program (RMP/PSM) in general accordance with state and federal regulations. The state risk management regulations, also referred to as the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) program, are codified in California Code of Regulations (CCR), Title 19, Section 2735.1, et. seq. The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) also regulates facilities with certain toxic and flammable substances. The federal regulations are codified in the Code of Federal Regulations (CFR), Title 40, Part 68. Both the California Occupational Safety and Health Administration (CalOSHA) and the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) regulate facilities with certain acutely hazardous materials under the Process Safety Management standards as defined in the CCR, Title 8, Section 5189 and CFR Title 29, Section 1910.119, respectively.



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Gallo Winery prepared the CalARP/RMP/PSM program to satisfy regulatory requirements and to demonstrate a commitment to evaluate and improve anhydrous ammonia and sulfur dioxide handling systems and practices at the facility. Many state-of-the-art safety features were incorporated into the ammonia and sulfur dioxide systems at the facility as part of the original system construction. In the unlikely event that a chemical release does occur at the facility, Gallo Winery personnel are trained in the appropriate response measures, with backup emergency services provided by the local fire department and the Stanislaus County Hazardous Mat

erials Response team. Gallo Winery will continue to improve ammonia and sulfur dioxide-handling safety through the implementation of the prevention program elements of the CalARP/RMP/PSM Program.

 

Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled

The Gallo Winery is located at 600 Yosemite Boulevard, Modesto, California in an area zoned for industrial use. The facility is west of Santa Rosa Avenue, which runs north and south along the east edge of the site. Gallo Winery is a family-owned business that processes wine by aging and bottling. Gallo Winery has been located at this site since 1934. The NAICS Code for the Gallo Winery is 31213.



Anhydrous ammonia is used at the facility in five independent processes at the State and Federal Program Level 3 (Program 3): four refrigeration systems and one pH adjustment of wastewater system. The ammonia refrigeration systems are closed loop systems. The process refrigeration systems contain approximately 19,729 pounds, 12,384 pounds, 12,384 pounds, and 12,660 pounds of ammonia, respectively. The refrigeration systems provide cooling to product chiller shells. The chillers are used to cool product as it circulates in sealed stainless steel tubing and across plates. A maximum of 32,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia is used to adjust the pH of wastewater leaving the Gallo facility as needed to keep the pH within regulatory requirements.  



Anhydrous ammonia is also used at the facility in two independent processes at the State Program Level 2 (Program 2): two refrigeration systems. Sulfur dioxide is used in four independent processes at Program 2: sulfur dioxide transfer, sulfur dioxide storage, finished wine sulfur dioxide injection, and sulfur dioxide transfer by Tank 3010.



The EPA RMP and OSHA PSM regulations have different threshold quantities of hazardous materials for their programs than the CalARP regulations have. All five Program Level 3 processes are covered by RMP, PSM and CalARP regulations. However, the si

x Program Level 2 processes are not covered by RMP or PSM regulations but are covered under CalARP. In addition, CalARP regulations for Program Level 2 processes are less stringent than those for Program Level 3 processes. Gallo Winery has chosen to manage its Program Level 2 processes to meet the more stringent Program Level 3 requirements.



The CalARP/RMP/PSM regulations require facilities to identify and evaluate chemical release scenarios resulting from potential failures of the chemical handling systems covered by the Program. Program 3 requirements of the CalARP/RMP/PSM apply to the Gallo Winery facility due to the quantity of ammonia used. Program 3 facilities are required to evaluate a worst-case release scenario (release parameters are defined by the regulations) for the facility and an alternative release scenario for each process chemical. The regulations define a worst-case release scenario as "...the greatest amount held in a single vessel...released as a gas over 10 minutes." An alternative release scenario is identified as a release that is more likely to occur at the facility.



This facility has prepared worst-case and alternative release scenarios. These are not summarized herein as recommended by EPA, but are presented in the CalARP/RMP.



General Accidental Release Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps



The CalARP/RMP/PSM regulations require a review of the accidental release prevention program and chemical specific prevention steps used by the facility. Gallo Winery has incorporated many safety features in the ammonia refrigeration, ammonia pH adjustment, ammonium hydroxide, and sulfur dioxide handling systems to prevent system failures and to mitigate potential releases. The predominant safety concern with closed-loop ammonia systems is inadvertent build-up of pressure exceeding pressure ratings or capacities of equipment due to ammonia expansion. The Gallo Winery ammonia systems are continuously monitored by automated control sy

stems that shut down components if deviations from normal operating conditions occur. Further, the systems are equipped with pressure relief valves on all pressure vessels and most, if not all, locations within the ammonia system where ammonia could become trapped. 



The predominant safety concern with the sulfur dioxide systems is inadvertent build-up of pressure exceeding pressure ratings or capacities of equipment due to sulfur dioxide expansion (heat and/or pressure). Care must be taken to not surpass 125?F (51.7?C) as the fusible safety devices in the sulfur dioxide cylinders melt at 165?F (74?C). The three dispensing systems are equipped with sulfur dioxide scrubber systems.



 

Other safety features at the facility include: 

?    emergency shutdown systems

?    security monitoring of the facility around the clock 365 days per year

?    component specific safety shutdowns

?    compressor and other system safeties are tested annually

?    pressure relief valves on all vessels, compressors, and most other areas in the system where trapped ammonia could build pressure

?    many of the ammonia pipes, valves and components are labeled

?    pressure relief valves are replaced at least every 5 years

?    operators receive ongoing training in operations 

?    maintenance personnel receive ongoing training

?    fire alarms and sprinkler system 

?    standard operating procedures for the ammonia system operation

?    standard operating procedures for operation of the sulfur dioxide systems

?    standard operating procedures for operation of the sump wastewater pH system



In addition to the physical features of the ammonia and sulfur dioxide systems at the facility, Gallo Winery has extensive administrative controls in place to maintain safe operation of the systems. Administrative controls include, but are not limited to: formal training programs for system operators and maintenance mechanics, a hot work permit program, a lock out/tag out program, a contractor safety program, incident inve

stigation program, mechanical integrity program, management of change program, pre-startup safety review program and a CalARP/RMP/PSM auditing and inspection program. Written standard operating procedures (SOPs) have been prepared for the ammonia refrigeration, ammonia pH adjustment, and sulfur dioxide systems at the facility. The SOPs will provide a basis for site specific operator training and a ready reference for operating and trouble-shooting the systems.



Gallo Winery is committed to maintaining the mechanical integrity of the ammonia and sulfur dioxide systems. A computerized preventive maintenance system is utilized to manage the preventive and corrective maintenance of the ammonia refrigeration systems. An inspection-based preventive maintenance system is utilized to manage the sulfur dioxide systems. Preventive maintenance at the facility includes shift, daily, weekly, and periodic inspection and calibration testing and overhaul of system equipment. The preventive maintenance systems are used to track equipment performance and to create reports that are used by maintenance personnel to monitor the frequency of repairs and deviations from normal operating parameters.



Five-Year Accident History



The CalARP/RMP/PSM regulations require a review of the 5-year accident history at the regulated facility. Gallo Winery reported no accidental releases of sulfur dioxide at the facility during the past 5 years. A single release of anhydrous ammonia vapor occurred on (date). The release of approximately 550 pounds was not detectable at the site boundary downwind of the release. No injuries either on-site or off site occurred. As a result of the release, Standard Operating Procedures were changed, refrigeration technicians were retrained, and purchasing receiving procedures were altered in an effort to prevent further releases of a similar type from occurring.



Emergency Response Program



In the unlikely event that ammonia and/or a sulfur dioxide release requ

ires emergency response occurs at the facility, Gallo Winery has a written emergency response program that identifies the roles, responsibilities and actions of the emergency responders. Gallo Winery will mitigate ammonia and/or sulfur dioxide releases at the facility. Gallo Winery will rely on community responders for medical assistance and public evacuation or protection in place, if necessary.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Changes to improve safety at the facility are ongoing. All of the mitigation measures suggested by the process hazard analysis revalidation team in 2014 are being addressed and/or implemented. The new suggested measures will be implemented during the next several months. The status of significant mitigation measures is as follows:

?    Spring return valves are used for all oil draining

?    Pressure relief valves have been replaced and will continue to be replaced every 5-years

?    Additional barricades to protect product chillers from accidental contact by motorized equipment have been installed

?    Administrative programs are being prepared and implemented

?    Preventive maintenance and inspection recommendations are being implemented



Gallo Winery will respond to all suggested mitigation measures promptly. Gallo Winery employee participation policy provides a mechanism for all employees to provide comments and concerns to Gallo Winery management. Management responses and support will be consistent with Gallo Winery's commitment to safe and environmentally responsible operations.



Gallo Winery recognizes that the CalARP/RMP/PSM is a continuous process for evaluating, monitoring, and improving anhydrous ammonia and sulfur dioxide handling operations at its facility. As such, this document and related attachments and program elements will evolve as Gallo Winery continues their ongoing focus and dedication of risk minimization and safety improvement for their employees and surrounding community. Gallo Winery will submit revised informatio

n if a change occurs that is considered significant and requires resubmission under the regulations. However, minor improvements/modifications to the CalARP/RMP/PSM, related attachments, and program elements will be incorporated consistent with Gallo Winery' internal review practices, and Gallo Winery will maintain the most current versions onsite. Thus, the most current version of the CalARP/RMP/PSM, related documents, and elements maintained onsite may vary slightly from the information in submittals made to Stanislaus County and other regulatory agencies.
